<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{array}[]{rclcl}\chi_{1}(L)&=&L\cap(T,\infty)\times Y&=&(T,\infty)\times
L%
_{1}\\
\chi_{2}(L)&=&L\cap(-\infty,-T)\times Y&=&(-\infty,-T)\times L_{1}\\
\end{array}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><msub><mi>χ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>∩</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><msub><mi>χ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>∩</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{array}[]{rcl}x_{1}&=&u^{3}-3u(1-|v|^{2})\\
z&=&(1/5)u^{5}-(2/3)u^{3}(1-|v|^{2})+u(1-|v|^{2})^{2}\\
\end{array}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><msup><mi>u</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mi>z</mi></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>u</mi><mn>5</mn></msup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>u</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

Let $\phi_t$ be its hamiltonian flow. Now just consider $\phi_1(L_0\times \mathbb{R})$.\\
 
\section{Proof of \ref{Main}} It is clear from \ref{Murphy} and from the proof of \ref{Chantraine} that in order to prove \ref{Main} we need to understand how the function $H_t$ as in the proof of \ref{Geiges} behaves as a legendrian wrinkle appears and disappears.\\

So consider the family of wrinkled legendrians whose front is given by $W_t:\mathbb{R}^2\to \mathbb{R}^3$ as $W_t(u,x_2)=(z,x_1,x_2)$, where
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{array}[]{rcl}\tilde{H}(p,v,t)&=&H_{t}(p,v)\ for\ v>T\\
\tilde{H}(p,v,t)&=&0\ for\ v<-T\\
\end{array}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>p</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>t</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>p</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>v</mi><mo rspace="7.5pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>r</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>v</mi></mrow><mo>></mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>p</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>v</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+5pt"><mn>0</mn></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>r</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>v</mi></mrow><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

Now set $y_1=(1/3)(u^2+x_2^2-t)$. Observe that $dz-y_1dx_1=[-(2/3)u^3x_2-2ux_2(t-x_2^2)]dx_2$. So we set $y_2=-(2/3)u^3x_2-2ux_2(t-x_2^2)$. For the higher dimensional case we just need to set $y_i=0\ for\ i>2$.\\

Now let us compute $X_t$.

Let $\phi_t$ be its hamiltonian flow. Now just consider $\phi_1(L_0\times \mathbb{R})$.\\
 
\section{Proof of \ref{Main}} It is clear from \ref{Murphy} and from the proof of \ref{Chantraine} that in order to prove \ref{Main} we need to understand how the function $H_t$ as in the proof of \ref{Geiges} behaves as a legendrian wrinkle appears and disappears.\\

So consider the family of wrinkled legendrians whose front is given by $W_t:\mathbb{R}^2\to \mathbb{R}^3$ as $W_t(u,x_2)=(z,x_1,x_2)$, where
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{array}[]{rcl}z&=&(1/5)u^{5}-(2/3)u^{3}(t-x_{2}^{2})+u(t-x_{2}^{2})^{2}%
\\
x_{1}&=&u^{3}-3u(t-x_{2}^{2})\\
\end{array}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mi>z</mi></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>u</mi><mn>5</mn></msup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>u</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><msup><mi>u</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

In order to extend $\alpha(X_t)$ in a tubular neighborhood of $L_t$ we must remove $u$ from the formula of $\alpha(X_t)$. \\

Observe that $\alpha(X_t)=(x_1/3)+2u(t-x_2^2)$. First using the formula for $x_1$ and $y_2$ we get
prevtext:
Now set $y_1=(1/3)(u^2+x_2^2-t)$. Observe that $dz-y_1dx_1=[-(2/3)u^3x_2-2ux_2(t-x_2^2)]dx_2$. So we set $y_2=-(2/3)u^3x_2-2ux_2(t-x_2^2)$. For the higher dimensional case we just need to set $y_i=0\ for\ i>2$.\\

Now let us compute $X_t$.

So for $\alpha=dz-y_dx_1-y_2dx_2$ we compute $\alpha(X_t)=(1/3)u^3+u(t-x_2^2)$.\\

In order to extend $\alpha(X_t)$ in a tubular neighborhood of $L_t$ we must remove $u$ from the formula of $\alpha(X_t)$. \\

Observe that $\alpha(X_t)=(x_1/3)+2u(t-x_2^2)$. First using the formula for $x_1$ and $y_2$ we get

g(t)&=&0\ for\ t\in[-3T,-2T]\cup[2T,3T]\\
